text: And it's not bad because it's not well-intentioned, but it's bad because it's not contextual. So when someone tells you to quit your job and chase your dreams, or they tell you to sit tight and grind through and build some experience before you go off and go start the company that you've always been thinking about starting, which piece of advice do you actually take? A lot of it depends on your situation, what you're considering, what skills and experience you actually have, and curiosity loops actually are this way of really thinking about how do you make your advice contextual.
speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
context: Lenny asks Ada to explain curiosity loops after she used this method to gather structured feedback for their podcast conversation. A curiosity loop is when you ask the same question to multiple people (around 10-15) to gather diverse perspectives rather than relying on one person's opinion. Ada explains that most advice fails not because of bad intentions, but because it lacks context for your specific situation - what worked for one person may not apply to your circumstances.
text_ko: 그게 나쁜 이유는 잘못된 의도 때문이 아니라, 상황에 맞지 않기 때문이에요. 그래서 누군가가 당신에게 직장을 그만두고 꿈을 쫓으라고 하거나, 아니면 조금 더 버티면서 경험을 쌓으라고 할 때, 어떤 조언을 실제로 받아들여야 할까요? 이건 정말 당신의 상황, 고민하고 있는 것, 가지고 있는 기술과 경험에 따라 달라져요. 그리고 호기심 루프(curiosity loop)는 조언을 어떻게 상황에 맞게 만들 수 있을지를 생각하는 좋은 방법이에요.
text_zh: 这并不是因为建议出发点不善良而糟糕，而是因为缺乏具体情境。因此，当有人告诉你辞掉工作去追求梦想，或者让你耐心坚持，积累经验再去创办你一直想创办的公司时，你究竟该听取哪种建议呢？很多时候，这取决于你的具体情况、你正在考虑的事项、你实际拥有的技能和经验。而“好奇循环”（curiosity loops）正是一种思考如何使建议具有情境性的方式。
text_es: Y no está mal porque no sea bien intencionado, sino que está mal porque no es contextual. Así que cuando alguien te dice que dejes tu trabajo y persigas tus sueños, o te aconseja que te mantengas firme y trabajes duro para adquirir experiencia antes de lanzarte a crear la empresa que siempre has querido iniciar, ¿cuál de esos consejos realmente sigues? Mucho depende de tu situación, de lo que estás considerando, de las habilidades y la experiencia que realmente tienes, y los bucles de curiosidad (curiosity loops) son una forma de pensar en cómo hacer que tu consejo sea contextual.

text: One thing was really telling, no one out of everyone we asked said 18. So that really dragged my partner up. And then the other thing that was really interesting was that we learned a little bit about executive function and the research around it. So executive function, which is your ability to make decisions and plans and be thoughtful peaks at the age of 30, and it's all downhill from there.
speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
context: Ada gives a personal example of using curiosity loops for non-work decisions. She and her partner were debating when their daughter should inherit their estate if something happened to both parents - he wanted 18 years old, she wanted 25. They asked trusted friends and family for input, discovering unanimous feedback against 18 and learning about executive function research that informed their final decision.
text_ko: 한 가지 정말 흥미로운 점은 우리가 물어본 사람들 중에 아무도 18이라고 답하지 않았다는 거예요. 그래서 그게 제 파트너에게 큰 영향을 줬어요. 그리고 또 하나 재미있었던 건, 우리는 실행 기능(executive function)과 그에 대한 연구에 대해 조금 배웠다는 거예요. 실행 기능은 결정을 내리고 계획을 세우고 사려 깊게 행동하는 능력인데, 이게 30세에 최고조에 이르고 그 이후로는 점점 떨어진다고 하더라고요.
text_zh: 有一点非常明显，我们问的所有人中没有一个人提到18岁。这让我的合伙人感到很震惊。另外一个有趣的发现是，我们了解到了一些关于执行功能（executive function）及其相关研究的信息。执行功能是指你做决策、制定计划和深思熟虑的能力，这种能力在30岁时达到巅峰，之后就开始下降。
text_es: Una cosa que fue muy reveladora fue que nadie de todos a quienes preguntamos mencionó 18. Eso realmente sorprendió a mi socio. Y lo otro que fue muy interesante es que aprendimos un poco sobre la función ejecutiva y la investigación relacionada. La función ejecutiva, que es tu capacidad para tomar decisiones y hacer planes de manera reflexiva, alcanza su punto máximo a los 30 años, y a partir de ahí comienza a decaer.

text: When I reflect back on what works across my early career, it really comes down in a nutshell to this career concept of explore and exploit. You're either in a mode of explorer where you have a bunch of unknowns and you're testing to see whether or not you like it, or you're exploiting, where you actually have found something that's really rich and really deep.
speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
context: Lenny asks Ada about her advice for early career professionals, noting her rapid career progression from entry-level at Microsoft to SVP of marketing at SurveyMonkey in seven years. Ada explains her framework of 'explore and exploit' - early in your career you should explore different roles and industries to find what you enjoy, then once you find something valuable, exploit it by going deep and building expertise in that area.
text_ko: 내 경력을 돌아보면, 결국에는 '탐색(explore)과 활용(exploit)'이라는 경력 개념으로 요약할 수 있어요. 탐색하는 모드에 있을 때는 여러 가지 미지의 것들을 경험해보면서 내가 좋아하는지 테스트하는 단계고, 활용하는 모드에 들어가면 정말 가치 있고 깊이 있는 것을 찾은 상태예요.
text_zh: 回顾我早期职业生涯中有效的经验，归根结底可以总结为“探索与利用”（explore and exploit）的职业理念。你要么处于探索者的状态，面对许多未知的事物，测试自己是否喜欢；要么处于利用的状态，发现了一些真正丰富且深刻的机会。
text_es: Cuando reflexiono sobre lo que ha funcionado en mi carrera temprana, se reduce a este concepto profesional de explorar y explotar. Estás en un modo de explorador, donde hay muchas incógnitas y estás probando para ver si te gusta, o estás en modo de explotación, donde realmente has encontrado algo que es muy valioso y profundo.

text: It's really easy to be a victim of inertia. It's really easy for all of us to be the frog where there are little things that make us uncomfortable, and we sit with them or we think, 'Gosh, it'll get better. The next manager will get better. I'm always one conversation or one promotion away from getting to that next step.' But you really have to be aware of your surroundings. You have to be aware of which way is the direction of the temperature of the water trending.
speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
context: Lenny asks Ada how to know when to stick with a difficult job that might lead somewhere versus when to leave. Ada uses the metaphor of a frog being slowly boiled alive - if you put a frog in boiling water it jumps out, but if you gradually increase the temperature it doesn't notice until it's too late. She explains this applies to career situations where people become victims of inertia, always thinking things will improve with the next manager or promotion.
vocabulary_highlights: one conversation or one promotion away
text_ko: 관성의 희생자가 되는 건 정말 쉽죠. 우리 모두가 불편한 작은 것들에 대해 그냥 앉아 있거나 '아, 다음 매니저가 더 나아질 거야. 나는 항상 한 번의 대화나 승진만 있으면 다음 단계에 도달할 수 있어.'라고 생각하는 개구리가 되기 쉬워요. 하지만 주변을 잘 살펴봐야 해요. 물의 온도가 어떤 방향으로 가고 있는지 인식하는 게 중요해요.
text_zh: 很容易成为惯性的受害者。我们每个人都可能像那只青蛙一样，面对一些让我们不舒服的小事，却选择忍耐，心里想着“哦，这会好起来的，下一个经理会更好。我总是离下一步的对话或晋升只有一步之遥。”但你真的需要关注周围的环境，留意水温的变化方向。
text_es: Es muy fácil caer en la inercia. Todos podemos ser como la rana que se siente incómoda con pequeñas cosas, y nos quedamos ahí pensando: "Bueno, esto mejorará. El próximo gerente será mejor. Siempre estoy a una conversación o a una promoción de dar el siguiente paso." Pero realmente debes estar consciente de tu entorno. Debes estar atento a hacia dónde se está moviendo la temperatura del agua.

text: I think that's a terrible trap that we should all try to avoid as we navigate our career paths and find the thing that's most optimal for us. Which is usually a mix of career success, but also meaningfulness and alignment in the work that we're doing with our values.
speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
context: Ada is discussing the importance of not getting trapped in a career path driven solely by external expectations or lifestyle requirements. She emphasizes that waking up late in your career feeling unhappy with your work, but unable to change due to financial obligations or others' expectations, is a terrible outcome. She advocates for finding work that balances career success with personal meaningfulness and alignment with your core values.
text_ko: 우리는 경력 경로를 탐색하면서 피해야 할 끔찍한 함정이라고 생각해요. 우리에게 가장 최적화된 것을 찾는 과정에서 말이죠. 보통은 경력 성공의 조합이지만, 우리가 하는 일에서 의미와 가치와의 일치도 중요하잖아요.
text_zh: 我认为这是一个我们都应该尽量避免的陷阱，在我们职业发展和寻找最适合自己的方向时，通常需要平衡职业成功、工作意义以及与我们价值观的契合。
text_es: Creo que es una trampa terrible que todos debemos intentar evitar mientras navegamos por nuestras trayectorias profesionales y encontramos lo que es más óptimo para nosotros. Lo cual, por lo general, es una combinación de éxito profesional, pero también de significado y alineación en el trabajo que realizamos con nuestros valores.

text: My hot take is that for the vast majority of people, they probably do not need a coach. And what I often push people on is if you're thinking about getting a coach, which is usually an indication that they have a feeling of being stuck or they have a problem that they're trying to solve, I ask them, 'What are your goals when it comes to coaching?'
speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
context: Lenny asks Ada about when people should consider getting an executive coach, given her work as a coach to founders. Surprisingly, Ada argues that most people don't actually need a coach and should first explore alternatives like mentorship through curiosity loops, taking courses, or building supportive communities. She challenges people to clearly define their coaching goals and consider if there are better ways to achieve those same outcomes.
vocabulary_highlights: indication that they have a feeling
text_ko: 내 생각에는 대다수의 사람들에게 코치가 꼭 필요하지는 않은 것 같아요. 보통 사람들이 코치를 생각할 때는 뭔가 막히거나 해결하고 싶은 문제가 있다는 신호거든요. 그래서 저는 그들에게 "코칭을 통해 어떤 목표를 이루고 싶으세요?"라고 물어봐요.
text_zh: 我的看法是，对于绝大多数人来说，他们可能并不需要教练（coach）。我常常会问那些考虑请教练的人，因为这通常表明他们感到困惑或有问题需要解决，我会问他们：“你在教练方面的目标是什么？”
text_es: Mi opinión es que para la gran mayoría de las personas, probablemente no necesitan un coach. Y lo que a menudo les pregunto es que si están considerando contratar a un coach, lo cual generalmente indica que se sienten estancados o tienen un problema que intentan resolver, les pregunto: '¿Cuáles son tus objetivos en relación al coaching?'
